http://www.nytimes.com/2006/02/23/education/23harvard.html?ex=1142485200...

Al, I am surprised to read that "Princeton does not stress a major (declared major) until the last year of school."  According to Princeton's website, "Most AB students declare their majors in mid-April of sophomore year."  One of the requirements at Princeton is the junior paper.  Doesn't a student have to know what they're majoring in when they select the topic?

"And let's not forget where Bill Gates and Mark Zuckerberg went to school."

And let's not forget that they both chose to drop out of Harvard and have never completed their degrees - and that Zuckerberg immediately moved to Palo Alto in 2004 to build his business and hire candidates for Facebook.

"Ukraine was a Western color revolution initiative to push into the Russian border" - two VERY disputable statements.
1. "Western (...) initiative" - Maidan involved hundreds of thousands of people. Ukrainians. "Western support" yes. "Initiative" - no. I have personally talked, many years ago, with Ukrainians longing to be in Europe, not Russia. It was their decision. You might as well say that American Independence was a covert French plot.
2. "push into the Russian border" - ??? Nobody wanted to annex Ukraine. What is actually true is the other way round - of all countries involved, it is Russia which recently expanded borders. Nobody else. Facts versus alleged intentions.

"They have already made the world a more ornery place."

Actually every war this century was initiated by the West, mostly with direct US backing. Even the current topics of Western outrage were actually done by the West.

Ukraine was a Western color revolution initiative to push into the Russian border, and we trumped our delight at their anger until we discovered they could do more than complain. Syria is an insurgency based in Western protected and operated safe havens, fueled by Western guns and money. The new South Sudan that is falling apart was a Western project and creation. Georgia DID attack Russia, and we encourage the lunacy and tried to lie about it for as long as possible. We start this, not the autocracies.

Perhaps it is our non-responsive and abusive governing elite that is keeping itself in power by being aggressive to keep the country united on a permanent war footing. Unstable within, we have been radioactive abroad.
Harvard and MIT will merge within the next 25 years. They have to.

Harvard is a lot of things, including both the arts and sciences, medicine and law, but not technology, and for a very good reason. Also in Cambridge, only two or three blocks away, is Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Why would Harvard want to try to compete with MIT?

Jonathan Clarke nicely delineated the 'main characteristics of neoconservatism'.

Barack Obama stands in polar opposition to the Bush administration neocons. We thankfully have a President who has established the multilateral, diplomacy-based, coalition-building Obama Doctrine.

' During January 2009, at the end of President George W. Bush's second term in office, Jonathan Clarke, a senior fellow at the Carnegie Council for Ethics in International Affairs, proposed the following as the "main characteristics of neoconservatism": "a tendency to see the world in binary good/evil terms", a "low tolerance for diplomacy", a "readiness to use military force", an "emphasis on US unilateral action", a "disdain for multilateral organizations" and a "focus on the Middle East".[67] '

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoconservatism

Never before has McCain's 2008 defeat seemed such a victory for world stability. The Southwestern heir to the Goldwater 'nuke em' strategy, McCain is hawkish to the nth degree. He'd have pursued war with N. Korea, Syria, Iran, and Russia in the last five years while hunting for a 'coalition of the willing' to join the U.S. in military madness.

We were spared the McCain Doctrine by the wisdom of the voters; we sensed in Barack Obama a new era of international relationships. War weary and economically stressed, we have gratefully embraced his war adverse, flexible foreign policy.

The Party of Opposition, massively over-invested in military capability, insisted on provocation while the President negotiated with world leaders on the Russian invasion into Crimea/Ukraine. The GOP brand of patriotism pours gasoline on open flames for self-serving political gain.

We can hope the spirit of President Eisenhower still lingers in the White House: the General had seen enough of the war machine to warn of the perils to democracy of the Military-Industrial Complex. Republicans don't claim Eisenhower, nor would he countenance war hawks and political profiteers.

President Obama keeps a lid on the boiling kettle of old-school anti-communist reactionaries. The Cold War has reemerged; inflammatory rhetoric and saber rattling turn up the heat.

To our benefit, Obama keeps a cool, clear head in crisis, domestic or international.

We have all been spared the horror of more warfare.
There may or may not be a shortage of V.A. doctors. However, there is no doubt whatsoever that there's an absence of integrity and management skill within the V.A.

Is that sarcasm? The weather in Boston was the worst I've ever experienced (granted, I grew up in a mild climate, but I did go to college in a frigid Midwestern town).
I live in CA now and I would never, ever judge a student for feeling weather was a consideration in choosing a school, particularly when choosing between two ivy league schools.

You're right that energy from wind and solar seems endless; we just need to harness it. You're wrong that conservation is part of the problem—we're running out of valuable materials like aluminum and copper, and do you think plastics are unlimited too?

The technology exists today for mankind to harness enough of the renewable energy from the sun, and increase the efficiency of the equipment and devices, for at least 10 billion people on earth to live with the same modern conveniences enjoyed by middle class people in developed countries. This would mean vehicles, planes and homes powered by electricity and hydrogen created from renewable sources.

Conservationists who tell us to tough it out on bicycles and by making our homes less comfortable are part of the problem. These actions won't be necessary, they won't solve the problem, and most importantly, preaching extreme conservation turns off Americans. (On the other hand, improved efficiency of our vehicles and devices is very popular with Americans.)

What is needed is a worldwide cooperative effort to have zero carbon emissions no later that 2025. Such an effort would cause the economy to boom worldwide. There would be no energy shortages, so to the extent wars are being fought over fossil energy, we should live in greater peace and security.

A global tax on fossil carbon emissions that increases annually could provide the necessary incentive to make this happen, and to pay for the renewable energy infrastructure. The Koch brothers and other energy barons might oppose it initially, but once they understood the profit potential of new energy sources, they would switch their investments from fossil fuel to renewable energy production.

Times have indeed changed. This year Stanford is going into Sailing Nationals (held on the east coast this year) ranked first in the country for both coed and team racing. :)  Top notch athletics is another thing that sets Stanford apart, and makes for a fun, spirited campus culture.
Stanford athletics also has money now. The sailing team is now a varsity team with a boathouse, lots of resources and  the ability to recruit top sailors.

When I was a Stanford freshman, we won the Pacific Coast sailing championship and went east for the nationals. We did not do very well, 5th of 8, but at least beat Pomona. The Ivies and Southern schools had coaches, equipment, etc. We were a club sport and intimidated by the Ivy League. So we decided to do what the Ivies were reputed to do and find consolation in NYC where the legal drinking age was 18. We would, of course, try to imitate the East Coast and stay at the Biltmore under the clock. When we called for the college rate at the Biltmore, the receptionist asked what college we came from. We replied, "Stanford." She asked, "Is that in Connecticut?" Nice to know that after sixty years, Stanford gets some East Coast recognition.
Get off your high horse already. Harvard produces many of the greediest CEOs and bankers on Wall Street, and worst politicians in DC.

Yes. We must live in the realm of the possible. Since American poltical discourse has moved so far into a soft corporation nationalism ( the Right) anything beyond total insanity is a net good. I would love if we somehow did not have belligerent nationalism as our proudest attribute, but that is the political landscape we have. Obama would have at least closed Guantanamo if Congress did not block this action.

I think that, truly, the disappointment of voters over Obama is that he has often given the appearance of, passively, giving up over issues about which he campaigned. This was especially true during his first term. There never seemed to be any fight in him over things that people really felt were important. Over and over he kept reaching out to the Republicans who were obsessively focused on defeating him at every turn.

Nick D:
Nothing in what I wrote should be construed to indicate I am "demoralized" or that voters who might be should "stay at home."
On the contrary, I said we should "conscientiously attend and commit ourselves."
Having "audacity to hope for change we could believe" in 2008, I voted for Barack Obama.
Betrayed and disappointed, yet disgusted by Republican obstructionism, and alarmed by the prospect of their attaining unfettered power, I voted again for Barack Obama in 2012, but only as the lesser of two evils.

Now that is still voting for evil, and we the people deserve better, and real choices in a democracy.
For that, to break the tweedle-dum Republican vs. tweedle-dee Democrat election stranglehold, we must have Ranked Choice Voting.
Comprehensive campaign finance reform is likewise essential.

I believe in causes, not candidates, and do not seek consolation in politics, yet am convinced, as the saying goes, "if you want it solved, get involved."

Meanwhile, gratefully I do count my blessings, but I don't care to say with any satisfaction, we've "come a long way, baby."

Whether you see the glass half-full or half-empty, it still is just half a glass, and it smells suspiciously of kool-aid.

It is a perfect measure of the intellectual vacuity and moral cowardice of our times (entendre intended) that we spend such serious discussion and take such profound relief over what awful things could have been, rather than conscientiously attend and commit ourselves to what should have been, and better be if we are to endure, let alone prevail, as a country worth existing.
Look at what's happening.
The undeclared war in Afghanistan will now continue for at least two more years.
Our military budget obscenely exceeds all the rest of the world, and our imperial presence everywhere has nothing to do with defense, but everything to do with hegemony.
Under Obama, the National Security State has achieved overwhelming dominance, while our democracy has become an oligarchy.
Yes, "Obama's foreign policy is a lot like his economic policy."
Duh.
Give him credit for preventing a financial collapse?
What he did was enable the perpetrators to profit further without consequence. The pompous constitutional lawyer has shredded our civil liberties, while becoming master of drones, killer at will.
Meanwhile, his "all of the above" energy policy threatens our security like nothing else ever.
History will regard his hypocrisy and duplicity in trying to maintain an unsustainable status quo with utter derision, and our failure to recognize and deal with that with deserved contempt.
So, because McCain would have been bad, we're supposed to feel consoled?

comments.commentBody: Hi Pablo : as a major donor to Berkeley I can personally vouch for the integrity of Berkeley's 'money can't buy you love' admissions policy. Go Bears!

I'm not sure Harvard is even that good compared to Stanford. Now if only Harvard's President Eliot had offered to establish the university in honor of Leland Stanford, Jr., when his father came to call. Then Harvard would be running both, and the Cambridge institution would be a leader in technology along with Stanford.

Bill Gates and Mark Zuckerberg succeeded in spite of Harvard, not because of it. Stanford, on the other hand, has supported its student entrepreneurs since the dawn of the internet age, which is why companies like Google, Yahoo, and HP trace their roots to The Farm.

People who go to Harvard just want to go to Harvard, doesn't matter what they major in, just pick something easy, the main reason for attending is to establish connections with the scions of world's rich and powerful, and to be able to tell people you went to Harvard.

People who go to Stanford actually plan to learn something and do something with their degree. In fact they often have a career goal in mind and choose Stanford because it's the best school to help get them there.
I went to Stanford.  It is the BEST four years of my life.  I LOVED IT SO MUCH!!!
Same with diabetics.

'The companies are going out of their way to discourage people with H.I.V. and AIDS from enrolling in their plans.'
Did anyone seriously think they wouldn't? Gotta keep up those profit margins. In a strange way, the success of HIV/AIDS treatment has created the problem, Back in the 1980s, i'm sure, the insurance companies had less of a problem with AIDS patients because they died too quickly to use up much of their benefits. No sooner had they covered the deductible than it was time to call the undertaker. Now, they neither die nor (a couple of highly publicised anomalous cases excepted) are cured. HIV pos and AIDS patients are the insurer's nightmare - they don't die, they don't get well, and their drug regimens cost a bunder.
Be careful what you wish for ...
Of course, if we had single-payer and some kind of rein on costs to make sure the price charged for the drug bore some vague connexion to the actual cost (plus a fair but not excessive profit for the members of the supply chain) ... but no, I jest or dream.

Well, you are simply incorrect - gun control works, only not when folks can drive a few minutes away and there's no gun control.

And you are incorrect about the "extra deaths are gun suicides" - there's also the alleged "accidents". You will note that many or most of the situations that are called "gun accidents", the incidents often involve clear and dangerous "negligence".

Of course, when you're talking about "lawless neighborhoods", you must be speaking of well-to-do suburbs - where in terms of fraud, prescription drug abuse, dwi, spousal & child abuse, etc., well, out in the 'burbs, the numbers of crimes committed per household are off the scales, tho' not so much with the prosecutions.

Gun advocates are often quick with the omissions.

Swamp Deville -- Suicides are 60% of all gun deaths each year. Accidents are only 2%. Homicides are 35%. The remaining 3% is scattered. Those are the DOJ statistics, and stay consistent over the last many years.

Certainly accidents ought not to happen. But they are 2% of the problem. Mass killings is far under 1%, nearer 0.1%.

Those 35% homicides are concentrated in only a few counties, and within those counties in only a few neighborhoods, which have violent crime of ALL kinds including gun homicides that are 15x the rest of the country.

Numbers define the real problem. What makes politics and headlines is not always the same as what the numbers show.

Isla Vista is a lawless neighborhood? Newtown, Connecticut? Blacksburg, Virginia? DeKalb, Illinois?

And that's just for starters.

Chicago's 30 year gun ban did no good. The killing went on, at record setting pace.

What Chicago proved is that the old conception of "gun control" does not work. More of what failed will not suddenly work.

We do need to end the gun violence that is epidemic. We won't do that by repeating what never worked.

Our gun homicide problem is limited to small geographic parts of the country where people victimized at 15x the rate of the rest of the country. They are mired in violence of all kinds, not just gun violence.

Three times as many people die by guns as just those killed by gun homicides. Those extra deaths are gun suicides, which are half of all suicides (essentially the male half). We have vast numbers of suicides, more than die in automobile accidents.

We need to focus the effort to rescue our people from lawless neighborhoods that submerge them in all sorts of violence, and we need to deal with our suicide epidemic. Old fashioned failed "gun control" won't do that, and so it won't solve the very real problems.

Remember that in the latest mass killing, the guy killed some of them with a knife. In Britain, knife killing has largely replaced gun killing, but it has not lowered killing there (which was always lower than here, even with guns).

The fight over gun control is a distraction from the suffering, from the real problems of real people.
Good grief - a pass to overbill, inflate and defraud!!! Where the heck is our government when things really need oversight?
No one went broke underestimating the intelligence of the American public.
I used to find European attitudes that describe the American public as crude, unsophisticated, unaware, and unintelligent, to be insulting.  No more.  They are spot-on.

In Europe, those that are the most sick -- or need the most health care -- pay the least for health care. In Italy, France and England (other countries, too), if you have cancer, have a chronic disease (like diabetes), are pregnant, you name it -- well, you pay nothing, not even the small co-pays that others pay for drugs. Nobody chooses to get cancer, HIV or become diabetic. It's sadistic that America punishes further those already punished by God.
